Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Dispose DI container every job loop of JsonConfigurationJob" (#7441) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Today, every time `JsonConfigurationJob.Init` is called, a new DI container is created replacing the reference to the previous one in `_serviceProvider`:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Jobs/blob/1b6f4a0bf6605fb676cccca6a839cabdb5c17f2a/src/NuGet.Jobs.Common/JsonConfigurationJob.cs#L66

This is a pit to fall in because DI containers can contain `IDisposable` instances (in particular singletons) and if we never dispose the previous container then the `IDisposable` instances inside of it will never be disposed, leading to leaks.

In short, a DI container is considered to "own" instances and `IDisposable` instances handed out by the DI container are typically the container's job to dispose -- especially singletons.

The `AutofacServiceProvider` container from Autofac.Extensions.DependencyInjection 4.2.0 does not implement `IDisposable` but the Autofac `IContainer` inside of it does. We should:

1. [x] Update to Autofac.Extensions.DependencyInjection version 4.3.0 or later
    - See https://autofac.readthedocs.io/en/latest/integration/aspnetcore.html#id3. We need this to make `AutofacServiceProvider` disposable
1. [x] Dispose the previous instance, if non-null. It will be non-null after the first job loop.

After this is done we can safely put `IDisposable` things in the DI container.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Put each job iteration into its own DI scope for JsonConfigurationJob descendants." (#8905) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

Follow up on https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7441.

### The Elevator Pitch

Currently, DI container used in jobs that are based on `JsonConfigurationJob` is [disposed](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Jobs/blob/af2c64924403c12ae45e5edb6012c23f052cea0e/src/NuGet.Jobs.Common/JsonConfigurationJob.cs#L83) on every job iteration. This may lead to an expensive object recreation on each iteration.

Instead, we can consider introducing a scope for each job iteration which would allow jobs to specify which objects are to be recreated on each iteration and which ones to transcend them.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Change to official NuGet.exe for tests (4.5.0 private build -> 4.5.3)" (#8904) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Before we moved to app services, we did not have a HTTPS-compatible domain name for staging slot on gallery. Now we do :). We can move away from a private build of nuget.exe which allowed for specific certificates to be trusted even for domain name mismatch.

I tried moving to 5.11.0 but this caused some test failures which need not be investigated or fixed at this time.

The private build of nuget.exe that is being replaced here is only test signed which means that a strong name bypass must be installed on the test agent. This is not ideal for centrally managed test agents.

With this change, we can run Gallery functional tests on managed agents that have the proper dependencies installed (namely VS 2015).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Change to official NuGet.exe for tests (4.5.0 private build -> 4.5.3)" (#8904) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Before we moved to app services, we did not have a HTTPS-compatible domain name for staging slot on gallery. Now we do :). We can move away from a private build of nuget.exe which allowed for specific certificates to be trusted even for domain name mismatch.

I tried moving to 5.11.0 but this caused some test failures which need not be investigated or fixed at this time.

The private build of nuget.exe that is being replaced here is only test signed which means that a strong name bypass must be installed on the test agent. This is not ideal for centrally managed test agents.

With this change, we can run Gallery functional tests on managed agents that have the proper dependencies installed (namely VS 2015).

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Re-add a11y to checkmarks and bangs in package details page" (#8901) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8897

- Adds the popovers into the new v2 package details page for reserved checkmarks (including alt tag) and vulnerable/deprecated bangs. 
- Narrator support also restored.
- There needed to be tab stops added to ID and version at the top. 
- I also removed a double tab stop on the versions in the version table.

Here are the changes (I pause and point at them): 
![44leShd08k](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14225979/144372641-9bc76ea9-97ed-44c2-9621-578728ce0c0d.gif)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Remove Mac Catalyst warning" (#11438) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "[DCR]: Adjust compatibility rules for Apple TFMs in .NET " (#11338) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

NuGet.exe, dotnet.exe

### Current Behavior

Current behavior is for the following TFMs to be compatible:

| TFM | Compatible With |
|--------------------|------------------------------------------|
 | net6.0-ios         | xamarin.ios                              |
 | net6.0-macos       | xamarin.mac                              |
 | net6.0-maccatalyst | xamarin.ios                              |
 | net6.0-tvos        | xamarin.tvos                             |

### Desired Behavior

We've decided that the xamarin.* TFMs should not be compatible with the corresponding net6.0-* TFM (for the Apple platforms).

Note that there's *no change* for net6.0-android / monoandroid.

### Additional Context

This is a design change that was approved here: https://github.com/dotnet/designs/pull/252

Note that this is technically not a breaking change (yet), since the net6.0-* TFMs aren't considered stable (stable release is Q2 2022).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Nuget Sign Support for CSP's and thus HSM's outside of the Windows Store" (#11437) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

Over at https://github.com/nuget/home/issues/5907#issuecomment-348030881 the parameters for CryptographicServiceProvider and KeyContainer were removed.  I would like those added back.
Certificates are inherently ephemeral things.  As it stands, I have to add my signing certificate to the Windows Cert Store as part of my Jenkins pipeline.  Setting up my HSM is accomplished as part of setting up my Jenkins agent, which is fine.  I would like to be able to inject my certificate dependency as part of my pipeline.  Then I could just have a simple "nuget sign -CryptographicServiceProvider 'some_hsm_provider' -CertificatePath 'mypath'"
The discussion on #5907 is not wrong in that the same goal can be accomplished with the use of the Windows Cert Store, which is what I'm doing.  It would be nicer for the CI/CD setting to have a more direct way to sign packages.


### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Rethink caching of nominations " (#5549) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
We have added the ability to specify NuGet related properties in MSBuild. 
The validation of these properties needs to be done at restore time rather than nomination, so that we throw the appropriate warnings.

This is not fully the case right now. 
The proposed solution would be to extend the nomination to include a property bag.
In addition we minht need to cooperate with Roslyn/SDK teams to potentially nominate top-level properties. 

Related to:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/1526#discussion_r125787206
https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5478#issuecomment-312142401
https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5478

//cc @emgarten

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet should be able to edit TFS versioned config files" (#5661) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Originally filed here: https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/85156/getting-error-when-attempting-to-enable-package-so.html?childToView=85997#

NuGet handles the editing of the packages config files for TFS versioned solutions but it does not do the same for the configuration files.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet Package Manager doesn't show versions available based on source " (#6773) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Moved 565735 here. 
https://www.screencast.com/t/JZum9Zcofxq

When I go to installed or updates after selecting a new source, and look for versions to install, I expect to see the newer versions. I do not.

Maybe I don't get it, but the UI is the same across Browse, Installed, and Updates so I expect the list to show me all versions I can switch to.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Unknown parameter should be treated as error" (#4065) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet product used: NuGet.exe

NuGet version: 3.4.4.1321

OS version: win10 v1607

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Open console

2. execute: `nuget restore dsgfasd asdf`

3. execute: `echo %errorlevel%`

Result:
```
>nuget restore dsgfasd asdf
restore: invalid arguments.
usage: (...)

>echo %errorlevel%
0
```

Comand failed to restore, because it got unknown paremeter. It may happen if You forget to put path in quotation marks. In my opinion it should return code > 0 to indicate error, and/or print something to stderr, because this is not success.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Failed to retrieve information from source, if source is empty and package was not found" (#5504) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @daxian-dbw on June 28, 2017 5:49_

## Steps to reproduce
`dotnet new console`

## Expected  behavior
No error and successfully restored

## Actual behavior
```
PS:52> dotnet new console
The template "Console Application" was created successfully.

Processing post-creation actions...
Running 'dotnet restore' on C:\Arena\Apps\dotnet2\bb\bb.csproj...
  Restoring packages for C:\Arena\Apps\dotnet2\bb\bb.csproj...
C:\Users\usr\AppData\Local\Microsoft\dotnet\sdk\2.0.0-preview3-006607\NuGet.targets(102,5): error : 
Failed to retrieve information about 'Microsoft.NETCore.App' from remote source 'C:\Users\usr\.dotnet\NuGetFallbackFolder'. [C:\Arena\Apps\dotnet2\bb\bb.csproj]


Restore failed.
Post action failed.
Description: Restore NuGet packages required by this project.
Manual instructions: Run 'dotnet restore'

PS:53> dotnet restore
  Restoring packages for C:\Arena\Apps\dotnet2\bb\bb.csproj...
C:\Users\usr\AppData\Local\Microsoft\dotnet\sdk\2.0.0-preview3-006607\NuGet.targets(102,5): error : 
Failed to retrieve information about 'Microsoft.NETCore.App' from remote source 'C:\Users\usr\.dotnet\NuGetFallbackFolder'. [C:\Arena\Apps\dotnet2\bb\bb.csproj]
```

## Environment data
`dotnet --info` output:
```

```







_Copied from original issue: dotnet/cli#7013_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Invalid fallback folder doesn't show any restore errors in visual studio" (#5591) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I manually deleted `'C:\Users\dfowler\.dotnet\NuGetFallbackFolder` from my hard drive and tried adding a dependency to my .NET Core project. When I added it, auto restore ran and the solution explorer showed this icon:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/95136/28107844-471ab208-669e-11e7-9642-e45ab87f98bc.png)

However, the assets file had no warning or error and the error list was empty:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/95136/28107872-5c8e7796-669e-11e7-8d28-ea43e9ed695a.png)

When running `dotnet restore` on the command line in the project it shows the following:

```
C:\Users\dfowler\.dotnet\x64\sdk\2.0.0-preview3-006729\NuGet.targets(102,5): error : Failed to retrieve information about 'Serilog.Sinks.ElasticSearch' from remote source 'C:\Users\dfowler\.dotnet\NuGetFallbackFolder'. [C:\Users\dfowler\Documents\visual studio 2017\Projects\WebApplication17\WebApplication17\WebApplication17.csproj]
```

PS: Earlier versions of `dotnet restore` shows the searched sources and configuration files and that was *very* useful information when debugging a restore failure. How do I get that information back?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The project dependencies in project.assets.json are named in an inconsistent manner" (#10255) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
---
**Issue moved from dotnet/msbuild#5860**
- Please respond to @MarkKharitonov.

---

_From @MarkKharitonov on Thursday, November 5, 2020 6:11:33 PM_

<!-- This is a template that helps us provide quicker feedback. Please use any relevant sections and delete anything you don't need. -->

### Issue Description
We are talking about .Net Framework projects using **ProjectReference**.

Some project entries in project.assets.json are named after the project name and some are named after the respective assembly name. The logic behind selecting one or another is unclear and makes it hard to write custom processing of this file. For example, to deal with the binding redirect hell.

### Steps to Reproduce
https://github.com/MarkKharitonov/PackageAssetsJsonAnomaly#the-anomaly - this repository contains 3 tiny projects and describes the repro steps in README.

### Expected Behavior
The names of project entries follow a consistent scheme - either project or assembly names, but not mixed.

### Actual Behavior
On a sample solution with 3 tiny projects, the project.assets.json file names one project dependency after the project name and another - after the assembly name.

### Analysis
I do not have an idea, but I am afraid it is related to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/64576860/why-does-console-build-generate-radically-different-project-assets-json-than-tha

### Versions & Configurations
https://github.com/MarkKharitonov/PackageAssetsJsonAnomaly#the-anomaly

### Attach a binlog
https://github.com/MarkKharitonov/PackageAssetsJsonAnomaly/blob/master/msbuild.binlog

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PackagesLockFile issues with projects with an assembly name different from the project file name" (#9417) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
#  Details about Problem

I have an issue in which the lock file generated by visual studio differs from the lock file generated by nuget.exe. This causes the error I get during a CI build:
NU1004: The packages lock file is inconsistent with the project dependencies so restore can't be run in locked mode. When I run a build in visual studio and having the lock file enabled, some project references have a different key. With visual studio, they are called "[productname].[component]", while doing the same using nuget.exe they are called "[companyname].[productname].[componentname]".


NuGet product used:
Nuget command line tool: 5.4.0.6315
VS version: 16.5.3
OS version: Windows 10

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem
I was unable to reproduce it with a small repro solution. But in our case
1. build the solution via visual studio with lock file enabled
2. now run nuget.exe:
nuget.exe restore <solutionname>.sln -LockedMode
3. wait for the error to appear
## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs
NuGet Version: 5.4.0.6315
MSBuild P2P timeout [ms]: 120000
MSBuild auto-detection: using msbuild version '16.5.0.12403' from 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Enterprise\MSBuild\Current\bin'. Use option -MSBuildVersion to force nuget to use a specific version of MSBuild.
C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Enterprise\MSBuild\Current\bin\msbuild.exe "C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Local\Temp\NuGetScratch\jpm2vzqy.nc5.nugetinputs.targets" /t:GenerateRestoreGraphFile /nologo /nr:false /v:q /p:NuGetRestoreTargets="C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Local\Temp\NuGetScratch\dcsqavr1.xl0.nugetrestore.targets" /p:RestoreUseCustomAfterTargets="True" /p:RestoreTaskAssemblyFile="c:\nuget\nuget.exe" /p:RestoreConfigFile="Website\nuget.config" /p:RestoreLockedMode="True"

Running restore with 8 concurrent jobs.
Reading project file <project file>.vbproj.
Persisting no-op dg to <project file>.nuget.dgspec.json
NU1004: The packages lock file is inconsistent with the project dependencies so restore can't be run in locked mode. Disable the RestoreLockedMode MSBuild property or pass an explicit --force-evaluate option to run restore to update the lock file.
Committing restore...
Writing cache file to disk. Path: <project file>.nuget.cache
Writing packages lock file at disk. Path: <project folder>\packages.lock.json
Restore failed in 78,05 ms for <project file>.
